Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I sat at the round table, my headset still warm from the morning’s calls. My manager’s praise echoed in my mind—“You’re on track to break the weekly record!”—and I felt the familiar pressure to keep the momentum going. The company had organized this lunch to celebrate our team’s success, and the spread was impressive: platters of sandwiches, salads, and pastries, all laid out for us. But as I scanned the table, my heart sank. None of the food had kosher certification. I could almost hear my mother’s voice reminding me of the importance of keeping kosher, of honoring our family’s traditions. My colleagues nudged me, urging me to dig in, to celebrate with them. I knew refusing might make me seem ungrateful or distant, maybe even risk the camaraderie that helped me thrive at work. But eating would mean compromising a core part of my identity. I stared at the food, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which part of myself I could afford to disappoint.
